Those upon whose hearts predominates what is not disliked in itself but for something else, such as those upon whom predominates the fear of death before repentance, or the fear of breaking repentance and violating the covenant, or the fear of weakness of strength in fulfilling the complete rights of Allah the Exalted, or the fear of the removal of tenderness of the Heart (Qalb) and its replacement with hardness, or the fear of deviation from uprightness, or the fear of the domination of habit in following accustomed lusts, or the fear that Allah the Exalted will abandon him to his good deeds upon which he relied and took pride in before the servants of Allah, or the fear of arrogance due to the abundance of Allah's blessings upon him, or the fear of being occupied with other than Allah instead of Allah, or the fear of being lured by the succession of blessings, or the fear of the exposure of the hidden dangers of his acts of obedience when there appears to him from Allah what he had not reckoned, or the fear of the consequences of people with him in backbiting, betrayal, deceit, and harboring evil, or the fear of what he does not know will occur in the remainder of his lifespan, or the fear of the hastening of punishment in this world and exposure before death, or the fear of being deceived by the adornments of this world, or the fear of Allah's awareness of his secret thoughts in his state of heedlessness of Him, or the fear of being sealed at death with a bad ending, or the fear of the precedent that was decreed for him in pre-eternity. All of these are fears, and each one has a specific benefit, which is treading the path of caution from what leads to the feared thing. So whoever fears the domination of habit upon him persists in weaning from the habit, and whoever fears Allah the Exalted's awareness of his secret thoughts occupies himself with purifying his Heart (Qalb) from whisperings, and so on for the remaining categories. Most of these fears, with certainty, is the fear of the ending, for the matter in it is perilous. The highest of the categories and most indicative of the perfection of knowledge is the fear of the precedent, because the ending follows the precedent and is a branch that branches from it after the interposition of many causes. Thus the ending reveals what was decreed by the judgment in the Mother of the Book. The one who fears the ending in comparison to the one who fears the precedent is like two men for whom the king issued a decree that could contain beheading or could contain the handing over of the ministry to him, and the decree has not yet reached them, so the heart of one of them becomes attached.

And the Heart (Qalb) is a house that is the abode of the angels, the descent place of their effect, and the location of their settlement. And the blameworthy attributes such as anger, desire, malice, envy, arrogance, self-admiration, and their sisters are barking dogs. So how can the angels enter it when it is filled with dogs? And the light of knowledge, Allah the Exalted does not cast it into the heart except through the intermediary of the angels: 'And it is not for any human that Allah should speak to him except by revelation or from behind a partition or that He sends a messenger and he reveals by His permission what He wills' (Ash-Shura: 51). And thus, what is sent from the mercy of knowledges to the hearts, indeed the angels entrusted with them take charge of it, and they are the sanctified, purified, and absolved from the blameworthy attributes. So they do not observe except what is pure, and they do not populate with what they have from the treasuries of Allah's mercy except what is pure and clean. And I do not say that the intended meaning of the word 'house' is the heart and of 'dog' is anger and the blameworthy attributes, but I say it is an alerting to it. And there is a difference between expressing the apparent to the inner realities and alerting the inner realities from mentioning the apparent while affirming the apparent. So the esotericists differ in this subtlety, for this is the way of consideration, and it is the path of the scholars and the righteous. For the meaning of consideration is to cross over from what is mentioned to something else, not restricting oneself to it. Just as the intelligent person sees a calamity for someone else, then there is for him in it a lesson by crossing over from it to being alerted that he too is exposed to calamities and that the world is on the verge of reversal. So his crossing over from someone else to himself and from himself to the origin of the world is a praiseworthy lesson. So cross over you also from the house that is the construction of creation to the heart that is a house from the construction of Allah the Exalted, and from the dog that is blamed for its attribute, not its form, which is what is in it of beastliness and impurity, to the canine spirit, which is the beastliness.

Inspiration (Ilham) does not differ from acquisition in the essence of knowledge, nor in its place, nor in its cause, but it differs from it in terms of the removal of the veil (Hijab), for that is not by the choice of the servant. And revelation (Wahy) does not differ from inspiration in any of that, but in witnessing the angel who conveys knowledge, for knowledge only occurs in our hearts through the mediation of angels, and to this is the indication by His saying, the Exalted: 'And it is not for any human being that Allah should speak to him except by revelation (Wahy) or from behind a veil (Hijab) or that He sends a messenger to reveal, by His permission, what He wills.' So if you know this, then know that the inclination of the people of Sufism (Tasawwuf) is towards inspirational sciences (Ulum Ilhamiyyah) rather than instructional ones, therefore they did not strive to study knowledge and acquire what the authors have compiled and research the mentioned statements and proofs, but they said: The path is to prioritize struggle (Mujahadah) and erase blameworthy attributes and cut off all attachments and turn with the core of aspiration (Himmah) towards Allah, the Exalted. And whenever that occurs, Allah is the one who takes charge of the heart (Qalb) of His servant and undertakes to illuminate it with the lights of knowledge. And when Allah takes charge of the matter of the heart, mercy (Rahmah) overflows upon it, and light (Nur) shines in the heart, and the chest expands, and the secret of the dominion (Malakut) is unveiled to him, and the veil of heedlessness (Ghurrah) is lifted from the face of the heart by the gentleness of mercy, and the realities (Haqa'iq) of divine matters gleam in it. So upon the servant is only preparation through pure purification (Tasfiyah) and bringing aspiration with sincere intention (Iradah) and complete thirst and constant anticipation in waiting for what Allah, the Exalted, opens of mercy. So the prophets and the saints (Awliya), the matter was unveiled to them and light overflowed upon their chests, not by learning and studying and writing books, but by asceticism (Zuhd) in the world and disengagement from its attachments and emptying the heart from its distractions and turning with the core of aspiration towards Allah, the Exalted. So whoever is for Allah, Allah is for him. And they claimed that the path in that is first by completely cutting off attachments of the world and emptying the heart from it.

Know that the honor of the intellect [al-'aql] is something that requires no strain to manifest, especially since the honor of knowledge [al-'ilm] has already become apparent through the intellect. The intellect is the source [manba'] of knowledge, its point of emergence [matla'], and its foundation [asas]. Knowledge flows from it as fruit flows from a tree, light [nur] from the sun, and sight from the eye. How then can that which is the means to felicity [sa'ada] in this world [al-dunya] and the Hereafter [al-akhira] not be honored? Or how can there be doubt concerning it, when even the beast, with its deficient discernment, holds the intellect in awe? Indeed, the greatest of beasts in body, the most ferocious in savagery, and the strongest in mightâ€”when it sees the form of a human, it holds him in awe and fears him due to its sensing his mastery over it, because of what he is specifically endowed with: the perception of stratagems. For this reason, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The elder [al-shaykh] among his people is like a prophet among his nation." This is not due to the abundance of his wealth, nor the grandeur of his person, nor the increase of his strength, but rather due to the increase of his experience, which is the fruit of his intellect. Therefore, you see the Turks, the Kurds, the uncouth Bedouin Arabs, and the rest of creationâ€”despite the proximity of their station to the rank of beastsâ€”by their very nature revere the elders. For this reason, when many of the stubbornly defiant intended to kill the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, and their eyes fell upon him and were adorned by his noble countenance, they were in awe of him. That which gleamed upon the brocade of his faceâ€”the light [nur] of prophethoodâ€”became visible to them, even though that was inwardly hidden within his soul [nafs] with the hiddenness of the intellect. Thus, the honor of the intellect is perceived by necessity. The intent here is only to relate what has come in the reports and the verses concerning the mention of its honor. And God has named it a light [nur] in His saying, the Exalted: "God is the Light of the heavens and the earth. The parable of His Light is as a niche..." And He named the knowledge derived from it a spirit [ruh], a revelation [wahy], and a life [hayah]. Thus He, the Exalted, said: "And thus have We revealed to you a spirit from Our command..." And He, the Glorified, said: "Or one who was dead, and We gave him life and made for him a light by which he walks among the people..." And wherever He mentions light [nur] and darkness [zulmah], He intends by it knowledge [al-'ilm] and ignorance [al-jahl], like His saying: "He brings them out from darknesses into the light."
